name: StreamTransformer
comment:
The target of a dart-async.Stream.transform call.

The dart-async.Stream.transform call will pass itself to this object and then return the resulting stream.

It is good practice to write transformers that can be used multiple times.

constructors.comment:
Creates a dart-async.StreamTransformer.

The returned instance takes responsibility of implementing (dart-async.StreamTransformer.bind). When the user invokes bind it returns a new "bound" stream. Only when the user starts listening to the bound stream, the listen method invokes the given closure dart-async.StreamTransformer.StreamTransformer-.transformer.

The dart-async.StreamTransformer.StreamTransformer-.transformer closure receives the stream, that was bound, as argument and returns a dart-async.StreamSubscription. In almost all cases the closure listens itself to the stream that is given as argument.

The result of invoking the dart-async.StreamTransformer.StreamTransformer-.transformer closure is a dart-async.StreamSubscription. The bound stream-transformer (created by the bind method above) then sets the handlers it received as part of the listen call.

Conceptually this can be summarized as follows:

  1. var transformer = new StreamTransformer(transformerClosure); creates a StreamTransformer that supports the bind method.

  2. var boundStream = stream.transform(transformer); binds the stream and returns a bound stream that has a pointer to stream.

  3. boundStream.listen(f1, onError: f2, onDone: f3, cancelOnError: b) starts the listening and transformation. This is accomplished in 2 steps: first the boundStream invokes the transformerClosure with the stream it captured: transformerClosure(stream, b). The result subscription, a dart-async.StreamSubscription, is then updated to receive its handlers: subscription.onData(f1), subscription.onError(f2), subscription(f3). Finally the subscription is returned as result of the listen call.

There are two common ways to create a StreamSubscription:

  1. by creating a new class that implements dart-async.StreamSubscription. Note that the subscription should run callbacks in the dart-async.Zone the stream was listened to.

  2. by allocating a dart-async.StreamController and to return the result of listening to its stream.

Example use of a duplicating transformer:

stringStream.transform(new StreamTransformer<String, String>(
    (Stream<String> input, bool cancelOnError) {
      StreamController<String> controller;
      StreamSubscription<String> subscription;
      controller = new StreamController<String>(
        onListen: () {
          subscription = input.listen((data) {
              // Duplicate the data.
              controller.add(data);
              controller.add(data);
            },
            onError: controller.addError,
            onDone: controller.close,
            cancelOnError: cancelOnError);
        },
        onPause: subscription.pause,
        onResume: subscription.resume,
        onCancel: subscription.cancel,
        sync: true);
      return controller.stream.listen(null);
    });

fromHandlers.name: fromHandlers
fromHandlers.comment:
Creates a dart-async.StreamTransformer that delegates events to the given functions.

Example use of a duplicating transformer:

stringStream.transform(new StreamTransformer<String, String>.fromHandlers(
    handleData: (String value, EventSink<String> sink) {
      sink.add(value);
      sink.add(value);  // Duplicate the incoming events.
    }));

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-async.StreamTransformer.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-async.StreamTransformer.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-async.StreamTransformer.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-async.StreamTransformer.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-async.StreamTransformer.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-async.StreamTransformer.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-async.StreamTransformer.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
